newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - Aug 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - Aug 20.

text.p: THE DOMINION
Law change to protect witness: Justice Minister Doug Graham will ask the government to change the law to allow the identity of witnesses to be kept secret in some court cases. Page 1.
More efficient CHEs expected: The government still wants "significant efficiency gains" from crown health enterprises to prevent them blowing out the health budget. Page 1.

Telecom chief urges growth policies: Telecom chief executive and former Reserve Bank deputy governor Roderick Deane has taken a swipe at the Reserve Bank for holding monetary conditions too tight and at the government for not setting a framework for growth. Page 1.
Greens back down from demand: The Green Party has backed away from a confrontation with its Alliance partners after some tough talking within the coalition. Page 2.

Consultation before decision -- Peters: Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters said on Tuesday that he had not made a decision on whether to take further action over the findings of the commission of inquiry into Cook Island tax deals. Page 2.

Super sums payable to estates, says Peters: Under the proposed compulsory retirement savings scheme, if retired people die before 75, their remaining pension payments, less any government top-up, will be paid to their estates as lump sums, according to Treasurer Winston Peters. Page 2.

Telecom 'aggressively' targeting costs: Telecom is aggressively targeting costs and capital expenditure and expects the benefits to show results for the second half of this financial year, chief executive Roderick Deane said on Tuesday. Page 17.

INL tipped for 48pc in Sky TV: Independent Newspapers is tipped to announce, possibly this week, that it has secured about a 48 percent holding in Sky TV from the United States consortium HKP Partnership. Page 17.
Macraes gets belated council clearance for expansion: Macraes Mining received belated council approval for its $120 million East Otago mine expansion on Tuesday. Page 17.
BIL directors appointed: Brierley Investments has appointed two new directors to its board, both connected with its Asian shareholding Camerlin. Page 17.

Fund managers targeted in super scheme criticism: Compulsory savings would line the pockets of fund managers without necessarily increasing total savings, State Services Minister Jenny Shipley said on Tuesday night. Page 18.
THE PRESS
Eight gang trials may be aborted: Eight pending gang trials in Christchurch may be aborted after a Court of Appeal ruling last week disallowing secret witnesses. Page 1.
Fair trial vital -- commission: The use of secret witnesses in trials had to be balanced with the accused's right to a fair trial, the Law Commission said on Tuesday. Page 3.

Telecom lifts profit 6.2pc: The telecommunications group announced a 6.2 percent improvement in bottom-line earnings to $188 million in the first quarter ended June 30, compared with the corresponding period in 1996. Page 30.

Ansett NZ profit expected: Ansett New Zealand is expected to announce its third consecutive operating profit next month, but the figure is likely to be down on the $9 million achieved last year. Page 28.

FCL Energy gains: Fletcher Challenge Energy said on Tuesday it would book a $37 million gain after prepaying a royalty obligation with respect to its previously sold methanol assets, and make a $19m after-tax charge for its interest in the Flour Bluff gas field in the United States. Page 28.
THE NEW ZEALAND HERALD
Telecom to ring up savings of $500m: Telecom is to chop capital spending by $500 million over the next three years in a cost control programme resulting from a just-completed Performance 2000 review.
